Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.
The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.
Does the concept of a/an Submodule need to be defined for a definition of a/an Length of an A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the length of an A-module explicitly relies on the concept of submodules. According to the definition, the length of an A-module M, denoted l_A(M), is the supremum of the lengths of chains of submodules starting from the zero module and ending at M. Each step in the chain involves a submodule that is strictly contained in the next submodule, culminating in the module M itself. Without the concept of submodules, it would be impossible to form these chains, as there would be no subsets of M that are closed under the operations of M and thus no way to measure the length of such chains. Therefore, the concept of a submodule is essential for defining the length of an A-module.
